text: <https://github.com/DLC-link/canton-billing.git>
<https://github.com/DLC-link/canton-billing>

<@U093Q4FPEJG> we can think a bit about the feature set of your backend process app.

I suppose some ideas:

The Billing Credential will have the following attributes:

Holder: String (that’s the party that is accepting the credentials and paying for them)
Id: String (usually like <customer-business-name>-cbtc-holder
Description: String
Claims : Array of Subject: String, Property: String, Value: String
Fee_Per_day: int (USD value of the amount to spend per day from this credential to us)
Billing_Period: int (in minutes, how often the payment happens)
Credential_Fees_Reserve_Amount: int (in USD, amount of USD they will lock up)
Credential_Fees_Target_Reserve_Amount: int (in USD, I forget what this is for :slightly_smiling_face: )

text:
So features of your app:

Happy Path
1. It should periodically poll every X seconds to see if any credentials are ready to be paid. Fetch all contracts and filter based on previous call to the `send_payment` function?
2. If any are ready, it can call the “send_payment” option for this bill, 
Error Handling
1. It can report if any one’s reserve gets too low (less then X days of billing remain)
2. It can report if anything fails

elements.text:

Happy Path
It should periodically poll every X seconds to see if any credentials are ready to be paid. Fetch all contracts and filter based on previous call to the
send_payment
function?
If any are ready, it can call the “send_payment” option for this bill,
Error Handling
It can report if any one’s reserve gets too low (less then X days of billing remain)
It can report if anything fails

text:
So I created a basic Postman Collection.

I also added scripts to some of them, do check them out. But, in essence, if you run them in sequence from top to bottom, each request will set up env vars for the upcoming requests.

text:
These three simple calls represent 99% of interacting we have to do.

Ledger end, Active Contracts, Exercise a choice (and a get parties is there, but only to help fill some env vars. in prod, those are from keycloak/hardcoded to the backend)

Robert Tera made updates to a canvas tab:

text:
So to recap, first we are building a prototype, to prove we can, and that everyone is familiar with the stack.
• JJ is launching a UI that can be used to issue/accept credentials
• Ferenc is working on a backend app, that can read active contracts of an 'operator' party, and call choices on them periodically
• I will be building the DAML
We meet in the middle

elements.text: So to recap, first we are building a prototype, to prove we can, and that everyone is familiar with the stack.
JJ is launching a UI that can be used to issue/accept credentials
Ferenc is working on a backend app, that can read active contracts of an 'operator' party, and call choices on them periodically
I will be building the DAML

text:
One other idea in the FE we might want <@U088UV6MKFE> is to show the user’s CC holdings, so they are sure they have enough CC to accept the credential? Do you imagine that Accepting the credential sends CC in the same step / tx?

Also, let’s not forget to add a DAML choice for cancelling the credentials by someone

text:
>  Do you imagine that Accepting the credential sends CC in the same step / tx?
This depends on the final architecture. If its the costudial way, it might be two steps, but due to the nature of DAML, it can still come from a single 'click' on the FE actually

> show the user’s CC holdings
This is a good idea, you could peep at the network tab of the Wallet UI, to see how they fetch Amulet balance

I don't fully know yet, how we can mimic this, but on DevNet, we can request FAP rights to ourselves. I think it just means we create a FeaturedAppRightV1 contract to ourselves, its in the linked daml contracts...
However, it should not matter for our testing, until we get to DevNet.

elements.text: Sidenote, but Fairmint is quite shamelessly farming in the open

Their validator hosts 85 parties, whose balances look exactly like this, just a deposit, and a slow spend to 0, earning their receiver app rewards.
I wonder how the GSF will deal with this

text:
That sounds very easy. I can summarize:
A backend/cronjob, that can transfer CC tokens of a local party.

Basically:
• you set up a new party 
• you send CC to it
• you periodically call the json_api, to send CC coins to your FAP
• $$
